title: How to Use a Smartphone for Focus Stacking

steps.headline: Make sure it is a smartphone, not a cellphone.
steps.description: You need to be able to see and choose a focal point using the screen.

steps.headline: Be sure that your camera and your smartphone can interface.
steps.description: For instance, Nikon has an app called SnapBridge that connects to any compatible smartphone.

steps.headline: Set up similarly as you do for focus stacking.
steps.description:
You'll need a:
Steady tripod
Camera mounted, firmly
Subject for photographing
Appropriate lighting

steps.headline: Set up your camera for your shot.
steps.description: You want to make sure that all, or most of your subject, will be able to have a sharp focus.

steps.headline: Connect your smartphone to your camera.
Choose various focus points and photograph each one.
steps.description: When shooting macros, you have very little depth of field, so you may need to take a lot of photographs to get a sharp image. This example uses only a few. You are only limited by your lens, camera, and software.

steps.headline: Stack your images in your chosen software.
steps.description: There are several options at a wide range of costs, from free options like Gimp to pricier ones like Photoshop.

steps.headline: Share the results.
steps.description: You will develop a new appreciation for macro photography!

text:
Make sure it is a smartphone, not a cellphone. You need to be able to see and choose a focal point using the screen. Be sure that your camera and your smartphone can interface. For instance, Nikon has an app called SnapBridge that connects to any compatible smartphone. Set up similarly as you do for focus stacking. You'll need a:
Steady tripod
Camera mounted, firmly
Subject for photographing
Appropriate lighting Set up your camera for your shot. You want to make sure that all, or most of your subject, will be able to have a sharp focus. Connect your smartphone to your camera.  Choose various focus points and photograph each one. When shooting macros, you have very little depth of field, so you may need to take a lot of photographs to get a sharp image. This example uses only a few. You are only limited by your lens, camera, and software. Stack your images in your chosen software. There are several options at a wide range of costs, from free options like Gimp to pricier ones like Photoshop. Share the results. You will develop a new appreciation for macro photography!
